newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian shares slip on slimmer volumes.
newsitem.headline: Russian shares slip on slimmer volumes.

text.p: Russian shares edged down on Tuesday on slim volumes in a correction from recent record highs, and dealers said the market's near-term direction was uncertain.
The Russian Trading System (RTS) 24-equity index slipped 3.26 percent to close at 268.37 from Monday's 277.40 on total volumes of $39.9 million, the NAUFOR brokers' association said.

"It is difficult to explain what's going on," said Martin Diggle, director at Brunswick Brokerage. "Today started with about a 3 to 4 percent drop and thin volumes. But in the past few hours it has gone up very strongly."
Irkutskenergo rose to $0.259 from Monday's close of $0.246. LUKoil wavered throughout the day, but was down to $14.10 after $14.17 on Monday.
UES closed at $0.153, up from $0.150, and Gazprom slipped to $0.427 after $$0.444.
Operators said President Boris Yeltsin's television appearance on Tuesday afternoon should help boost the market on Wednesday.
An alert Yeltsin, recovering from pneumonia, was shown in a Kremlin meeting, the first new pictures of him since January 6.
"It will certainly help sentiment, but I don't think the correction was triggered by the president's health," Diggle said.
Dealers said most buyers were Russian, in contrast to the Western funds that drove last week's red-hot buying.
Brokers said shares would be jittery as buyers become accustomed to new, near-record price levels, but said buyers should look forward to a profitable year.

"Gazprom has been cyclical since the years...It was at $0.49, and now is at $.42. I see a lot of Gazprom back orders. I don't see it going below $0.40 again," said Dan Rapoport, institutional equity sales director at CentreInvest Securities.
Megionneftegaz rose 7.76 percent to $5.20 from $4.90 after the oil producer announced it planned to issue level-one American Depositary Receipts in the first quarter of this year.
